individual_metadata.synopsis: Raphael is encountered at the beginning of the Shar Temple. He briefs the player about the Orthon - the devil he mentions - either telling them that he personally wants it dead, or that it is between the player and their objective. He then saves them from a trap and warns them about the dangers of the temple, before vanishing.!!! Don't remove REALLY_ASTARION tag check from the OOM branch!!!
individual_metadata.how_to_trigger: Origin Debug Book (Ctrl + Shift + 7)Astarion - Act 2 - Teleport to Act 2Astarion - Act 2 - Finding Raphael - Teleport to RaphaelMove forward (to the entrance of Shar Temple) and Raphael will start a conversation with you.

automatic_ordering.reasoning: There is only one session in the provided data (with an empty string as its name). Since the data does not include any other sessions or any details that suggest a causal or sequential relationship with another session, no ordering constraints can be deduced. Additionally, with only one session present, there are no conflicts or mutually exclusive conditions identified.

73.context: CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see Raphael casually leaning against a large tomb very near to the Thorm family catacombs entrance. When he sees us , he stands normally, smiles and greets us theatrically with a limerick.

170.speaker: Player
170.text: How long were you skulking there, practicing that rhyme before I arrived?

36.speaker: Player
36.text: Did you now? And what danger would that be?

23.speaker: Player
23.text: Speaking of my tale, I do have one thing to ask you. A proposal of sorts.

38.speaker: Player
38.text: Hardly, this is something else entirely.

119.speaker: Player
119.text: Long ago, some Infernal runes were cut into my back. I'd rather like to know what they say.

6.speaker: Raphael
6.text: Given your appalling behaviour when we last met, I really shouldn't be helping you. But I can't resist. You're just so fascinating.

151.speaker: Raphael
151.text: So indulge me. And I'll indulge you.

155.speaker: Raphael
155.text:
Our hero thought but of treasure ahead,
Did not consider the peace of the dead...

110.speaker: Raphael
110.text:
Through the dark they went creeping,
And awoke what was sleeping...

11.speaker: Raphael
11.text: A new grave they dug, which they themselves fed.

143.speaker: Player
143.text: I'm not afraid of the dark.

101.speaker: Raphael
101.text: This is no night you can sleepwalk through, somnambulist, you must be wide, wide awake to survive.

85.speaker: Raphael
85.text: I've grown quite fond of you, you know - in my way. I thought it only fair to warn you about the dangers ahead.
85.context: CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) When he says ‘the dangers ahead’ he gestures generally behind him, towards the entrance of the Thorm family catacombs.

136.speaker: Player
136.text: Go on then. Spit it out.

145.speaker: Raphael
145.text: Decorum, Karlach. A modicum, I beg of you. Especially considering what awaits you.

164.speaker: Raphael
164.text: Oh, we both know they are soon to be revealed.

28.speaker: Raphael
28.text: It would be pointless of me to try to bar you from entering, but I can... set the scene as it were. Prepare you for your role.

61.speaker: Raphael
61.text: There is a stage down in the dark upon which a great drama has suspended itself in time.

8.speaker: Raphael
8.text: Its actors dwell there still, mired in the languor of their long-tired scenes.

44.speaker: Raphael
44.text: If you, however, through the dark go creeping and awake what is sleeping...

30.speaker: Raphael
30.text: Chances are many more graves than yours alone will soon be fed.

46.speaker: Player
46.text: Paint me a clearer picture than that.

75.speaker: Raphael
75.text: There is a creature that lurks in silence and shadow - a creature who, like me, is very much of the infernal persuasion.

51.speaker: Raphael
51.text: Should it make its way out through the very doors you are about to brazenly swing open, you'll have unleashed a pestilence upon this realm.

158.speaker: Raphael
158.text: In truth, it is carnage incarnate. So if you meet the devil of which I speak, kill it. Consider no other course of action.

120.speaker: Player
120.text: All right, a different question - can you tell me what the Infernal scars on my back mean?

159.speaker: Player
159.text: You're still only telling me half of what you really know. I can tell.

90.speaker: Raphael
90.text: This creature and I go back a long way. I admit it would be in my best interest as well should it remain trapped in the dark, or misplace its head perhaps.

88.speaker: Karlach
88.text: What are we talking here? Lemure? Pit fiend? Orthon?

69.speaker: Player
69.text: Are you afraid of this creature, Raphael?

67.speaker: Player
67.text: Anything else I need to know?

128.speaker: Raphael
128.text: I should not relish its reacquaintance. Let's leave it at that.

80.speaker: Player
80.text: Before you go - what can you tell me about the Infernal scars on my back?

72.speaker: Player
72.text: What are we talking here? Lemure? Pit fiend? Orthon?

43.speaker: Raphael
43.text: You have it in you to author a thrilling finale, if... if you heed this warning:

71.speaker: Raphael
71.text: Do not underestimate this opponent. At best you will have the blink of an eye to strike.
71.context: CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) He leans in and suddenly any trace of playfulness or sarcasm has drained from his voice. In this very moment he’s dead serious.

118.speaker: Raphael
118.text: Strike first. Strike true. Defy the odds, for they are distinctly in its favour. That much I owe the bastard to concede.

74.speaker: Raphael
74.text: After all, if there is one rule I hold dear, it's that one must always give the devil his due.
74.context: CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) He steps back and his more casual, more sarcastic self returns, in contrast with the earlier two nodes.

34.speaker: Player
34.text: Sounds like an acquaintance I'd quite like to make actually.

14.speaker: Player
14.text: I always knew you're a coward at heart.

89.speaker: Raphael
89.text: Believe me, I am not telling you half of what I know.

65.speaker: Player
65.text: I'll consider my actions when I get there.

163.speaker: Raphael
163.text: I'd rather you stick to my script, but you do have an unfortunate tendency to improvise.

116.speaker: Player
116.text: I'll deal with this menace, but do not think us allies, fiend.

62.speaker: Raphael
62.text: I'd never think us allies, paladin. Perish the thought - and the devil too, if you'd be so kind.

150.speaker: Player
150.text: On the other hand, the enemy of my enemy, et cetera.

64.speaker: Raphael
64.text: I'm a mentor, not your mother. I don't wax poetic about boogeymen to keep you on the straight and narrow.

97.speaker: Raphael
97.text: By all means, stray. Explore. Hunt. Just don't indulge in the illusion that you're the greater hunter.

154.speaker: Raphael
154.text: I'll be pleased to follow up on your little escapades in your camp one of these nights. Should you live to tell your tale, that is.

132.speaker: Raphael
132.text: And don't think I've forgotten your tale, Astarion.

156.speaker: Raphael
156.text: When the beast is dead, I'll consider that payment enough to translate those scars of yours.

78.speaker: Astarion
78.text: A fairer deal than I expected.

95.speaker: Raphael
95.text: You wound me, spawn. I always deal fairly.

124.speaker: Raphael
124.text: And we'll close this particular deal soon enough - vanquish the beast, and all will be revealed.

149.speaker: Astarion
149.text: Wait! Before you go, I have a proposal of my own.

100.speaker: Raphael
100.text: A proposal? If you're hoping to taste my blood, little vampling, think again. It burns hotter than Wyvern Whiskey.

104.speaker: Astarion
104.text: My old - well, a long time ago someone carved some runes into my back. I'd rather like to know what they say.
104.context: NodeContext: Starts saying 'my old master...' but stops himself

37.speaker: Raphael
37.text: It's something of great importance to your master. But is it a love letter, a warning, or a deed of ownership? I can give you all the gory details.

84.speaker: Raphael
84.text: And I will - once the beast that lurks below is vanquished, and sent back to the Hells.

121.speaker: Player
121.text: What are you talking about, Astarion? What scars?

98.speaker: Raphael
98.text: You haven't told them? And you've kept your clothes on this whole time? How unlike you.

70.speaker: Raphael
70.text: Why not let them see? Don't be shy.
70.context: CinematicNodeContext: Raphael waves his hand and Astarion's shirt magically disappears.

86.speaker: Astarion
86.context: NodeContext: Fed up with this shit (a devil just magicked away your shirt.)

12.speaker: Raphael
12.text: Don't pout, spawn. Just destroy the beast and I'll happily reveal your secrets instead of your skin.

123.speaker: Astarion
123.text: Yes, fine, we'll kill this damn creature of yours.

9.speaker: Raphael
9.text: Then we have an understanding. I look forward to our next meeting.

42.speaker: Raphael
42.text: Scars often tell such wonderful stories - I think yours might be truly exquisite.
42.context: CinematicNodeContext: To Astarion. Raphael disappears if it's the end of the dialogue.

146.speaker: Player
146.text: Why didn't you tell me earlier?

29.speaker: Astarion
29.text: I - perhaps I should have, but I'm not used to asking for help and being met with, well... help.

130.speaker: Astarion
130.text: But what's done is done, so how about we stop discussing it and just kill this beast?

105.speaker: Player
105.text: Gods... the carving must have been excruciating.

96.speaker: Astarion
96.text: Cazador worked on it from dusk until dawn, all with an ancient blade he called his 'needle'. Cutting and tearing, starting over if I screamed or winced too much.

49.speaker: Player
49.text: All I know is you have us doing odd jobs for a devil.

141.speaker: Astarion
141.text: It could be infinitely worse. We seem to be rather good at killing things.

54.speaker: Astarion
54.text: Let's just go. Standing here chatting gets us nowhere.

109.speaker: Astarion
109.text: Although I should probably get dressed first...

5.speaker: Player
5.text: Deal - we'll help you, if you help Astarion.

3.speaker: Astarion
3.text: What's not to like? We kill some horrible beastie, and I get what I want in return. Everyone's happy.

26.speaker: Raphael
26.text: Then we have an understanding. I look forward to our next meeting.

115.speaker: Raphael
115.text: Scars often tell such wonderful stories - I think yours might be truly exquisite.
115.context: CinematicNodeContext: To Astarion. Raphael disappears if it's the end of the dialogue.

107.speaker: Player
107.text: We're not doing your dirty work, Raphael.

21.speaker: Astarion
21.text: Let's not be so hasty - we might enjoy doing the devil's dirty work.

7.speaker: Astarion
7.text: And it's all for a good cause - me.

134.speaker: Raphael
134.text: Listen to your friend. What I'm asking isn't unreasonable - when you meet the beast, you'll realise that killing it is the wisest course.

127.speaker: Raphael
127.text: And once the deed is done, our next meeting will be most productive, Astarion.

31.speaker: Player
31.text: How do you even know there's danger ahead?

53.speaker: Raphael
53.text: My dear friend, I think you'll find I play my part in many a plot indeed.

57.speaker: Raphael
57.text: Cannot the same be said for you these days, True Soul?

153.speaker: Player
153.text: I know my role even if you don't: it is to kill Ketheric.

48.speaker: Raphael
48.text: I had an inkling that was one of your main motivators. Delighted to see it confirmed.

18.speaker: Raphael
18.text: You're welcome to give it your best shot, of course. It's just that, well, the man has proven to be more or less resilient to death.

76.speaker: Raphael
76.text: Which is not the only obstacle you're likely to face...

160.speaker: Player
160.text: Just cut to the chase, will you.

33.speaker: Raphael
33.text: I already did. If through the dark you go creeping and awake what is sleeping...

148.speaker: Player
148.text: So you expect me to turn and walk away?

135.speaker: Raphael
135.text: I admit, it isn't my primary interest. Not by any stretch.

91.speaker: Player
91.text: A warning, no less. Don't tell me you're worried about me.

114.speaker: Player
114.text: How long have you been standing around practicing that little recital?

167.speaker: Player
167.text: Are you saying there's treasure ahead?
